The question was posed to me by a fellow hacker at the HackerDojo down in Mountain View, Silicon Valley last year. while me and @16468233438 were serving out samples of our cacao drink

*_How do you measure biodiversity in an ecosystem and ensure that the cabruca system actually helps with biodiversity?*_

A few months ago I did manage to find a lot of mathematical formulas to measure biodiversity in an ecosystem. The most common one is the *_Shannon diversity index*_.

https://www.statology.org/shannon-diversity-index/ 

The math is easy, the main challenge lies in gathering the data and compiling the biodiversity index of a farm. 

Farmers are busy. And it’s comes across as additional work for what would be considered marketing purposes from their perspective

Working through the statistics and thinking through the available technology that is out there, seems the least effortful way to implement the measurement of this would be to use a drone mounted with a high resolution camera 

The video from the drone would be piped to an AI model that then identifies and quantifies all the different species of plants and animals surfaced in the video stream

And if we flew the drone in a fixed pattern across the farm from _east to west, north to south_ we should end up with a 80% accurate count of the different species in the environment 

If this same methodology is applied on all the farms we survey, we will end up with a good enough tabulation overtime. 

We can then justify why we decided to support one farm and not another farm.

And each farm in our support network will come associated with a Shannon index 

And people who buy our bags of cacao nibs could then scan the associated QR code and very quickly see the statistics of the farm the cacao is from. 

If we want ensure the records against being tempered, we could write the records on the blockchain signed with our key
